required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Blood Pressure During Rate Control in Patients With Tachycardic Atrial Fibrillation at the Emergency Department
clinical_study.official_title: Blood Pressure During Rate Control in Patients With Tachycardic Atrial Fibrillation at the Emergency Department

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of this study is to analyse blood pressure during rate control therapy in patients with tachycardic atrial fibrillation in a real-world emergency cohort.

detailed_description.textblock:
Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the primary clinical problem in 3.3% to 10.0 % emergency department (ED) admissions. Rate control is an integral part of the management of symptomatic tachycardic AF patients.
According to the recent guidelines beta-blockers, digoxin, the calcium channel blockers diltiazem and verapamil, amiodarone or combination therapy should be considered for rate control. Haemodynamic side-effects in particular hypotension may occur. Heart rate and blood pressure behavior in an ED population during rate control therapy in patients with tachycardic atrial fibrillation will be analysed.

primary_outcome.measure: Mean and maximum blood pressure difference between before (baseline) and during/after medication.

intervention.description: Rate control according to the Atrial fibrillation - ESC Guidelines 2016

study_pop.textblock: We plan to include all patients admitted to the Emergency Department of the Medical University Vienna with tachycardic AF receiving rate control therapy.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age > 18 years
- Atrial fibrillation or atrial flutter and heart rate ≥ 110 bpm
- Indication for rate control
- Informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
• Inclusion criteria not met
